factory today.
So first, as we are now data is the new oil, this data
is really helpful for us to make better decisions
and give us a lot of insights.
However, a lot of this data is also very sensitive.
And handling the sensitive data poses a lot of challenges.
So for example, we continue to see really large scale data
breaches, where a capitalist compromise
sensitive and still sensitive information
about hundreds of millions of users
being in a single attack.
And also, we continue to see that users are losing trust
incomplete as a lot of users' data,
maybe mishandles abuse and so on.
So as we handle sensitive data, there
are a number of challenges that we need to address.
One is that the infrastructure may be untrusted.
Applications may have compromised the compute infrastructure.
All right, the application itself may be untrusted,
because again, attackers may have launched some malicious
applications, or the applications may have vulnerabilities.
And also, some applications may have undesirable data
leakage.
So to address these problems, as OISIS labs,
we have been developing new solutions,
where we essentially build the next generation
blockchain smart contract platform
with greater scalability and privacy protection,
where we enable scalable smart contract execution,
and also enable, for the first time,
confidential smart contracts.
And also, on top of the platform,
we build SDKs to enable privacy preserving
and analytics execution.
So today, I'll talk about some new research
that we have done at Berkeley and also OISIS
with decentralized federal students.
So first, let's look at a multiplicity example
in fraud detection.
So when banks provide financial services,
for example, in the longs, they need to detect fraud.
And typically, how this works is that each bank uses its own data
to build, for example, some machine model for fraud detection.
However, as we know, it would be much better
if these banks can actually share that they
can build one fraud detection instead of the individual ones.

can essentially be more effective.
Part of this can happen today because there's

and also there may be miscellaneous incentives and so on.
So how can we address this problem?
So there are a number of alternative solutions
that we can consider.
So with one alternative solution,
we can use something called the federal solution.
So federal training is a mechanism that is an approach
that actually has seen some adoption deployments
at Google and Apple, for example, where essentially,
using federal rating, uses data and stores locally
on their mobile phones.
And then the central server at Google or Apple
can coordinate these different local devices
to collectively train a machine model
in this distributed fashion.
So in this case, with federal training,
it takes an iterative approach where in round I,
it has the information of this global model that is being trained.
And then this model is distributed to the local devices.
And then each local device uses its own local data
to try to update this model using what we call breeding update.
And then this breeding update is then sent back
to the central server to then the central server
that aggregates these breeding updates
to then create the next region of the model.
And then this continues.
So in this way, the advantage is that each user's data
is stored locally, is now actually uploaded to the cloud
or to the central server.
But still, in this case, it still needs
a central server to coordinate this federal training.
And there are, of course, a number of challenges
of which you might be used this type of approach
to address the problem that I just mentioned.
For example, in this case, one different bank
wants to collaborate.
The question is, who should actually host the central server?
I feel like you don't want to rely on these industries
just then, so you don't want to actually have
anyone hosting the central server.
And also the central server, by relying on the central server,
it can create issues, for example,
if they became malicious or they can also
give the central server some unfair advantage.
So in contrast to this federal training model, which
relies on the central server to coordinate
distributed devices to together train
eventually the other in the distributed way.
Another alternative solution is what's called
a peer-to-peer solution.
In this case, essentially the different devices
form a peer-to-peer network.
There is no central server.
And essentially, the different devices
will communicate through this peer-to-peer network
with its neighbors and then through, again,
an iterative approach to try to together
updates this machine-in-amount to utilize the local data

is that in the setting, we don't need
to trust any central server, because there's
a simply no central server.
However, the challenge here is that in this peer-to-peer
there's a significant overhead for communication and so on.
And especially when the number of clients becomes large.
And also, there is more privacy challenges in the field.
So in our recent work, we proposed a new paradigm
that we call "essentialized-fantasy-ready."
Where we combine, essentially, the best of both worlds.
Both using a decentralized setting,
where we don't rely on any central server.
